text: - Hi, it's Andy.

I'm back here on Thursday, the
last full day of re:Invent,

and I had a few things I
was gonna mention today
that I was excited about sharing.

You know, the first is
really around SageMaker.

So our customers have used
SageMaker very expansively
over the last number of years

because it's the easiest
way to organize your data,

to build AI models and then
to deploy them at scale.

And we have loads of
customers who do this,

some examples of Perplexity
and Workday and NatWest.

But I would say today that
most companies are starting
to standardize on top of SageMaker
when they're building their own AI models.
But what we've seen over the last year

or two is that increasingly
customers want their AI
and their analytics in the same space.

And we have a leading
array of analytics services
that are really good at various jobs.
So like we have Redshift,
which is a scalable data warehouse.
We have EMR,

which lets you process petabyte
scale workloads like Spark.
We have things like OpenSearch,

which largely lets you
do operational analytics.
We have all these, you know,
we have Glue, which does data integration.
We have all these analytics services,

except people have to go
to each of these services
when they want to use them.

And what we started
hearing from customers was,

"I really wished I could
use your leading tools
and building blocks,

but from the same place
and where my AI is."
And so we realized

that we needed to make
this easier for all of you,

and we thought about should
we just build a new service
and call it something different?
And then we realized the center right now
of a lot of these AI workloads
and increasingly analytics is SageMaker.

And so we built a brand
new addition of SageMaker,
our next generation of SageMaker,
which we just announced this week,
and it has two key components for you.

It, first, has something
called the SageMaker Lakehouse.

And so what we've done is
we've taken all your key data
from S3 and now S3 tables and Redshift

and a whole bunch of third
party SaaS applications you use
like Salesforce or ServiceNow or Zendesk.

And we make all that data
accessible in the new SageMaker.
So you have all your data in one place.

And then also we've
built a second component,
which we think of as the,
we call the SageMaker Unified Studio.
So we took all the studios,

which you really think of
those as the abstraction tools
that make it easy for you to operate
across all those analytics services.
So studios from SageMaker, from Bedrock,
from Redshift, from Glue,
from Athena,
all these different studios,

and put them all together
in a unified studio.

So now you have all the data
you want to do analytics
and AI together in the Lakehouse,

and then all the
abstractions in the studios

in which you normally
operate on that data,
all accessible in one place,
much easier to use.
And it's also much easier
for you to collaborate with other people

because you can be working
on different pieces
but then all those components
and all those tools are in one place.
So customer's very excited about this.
I am too.

I think it's gonna be really
a game changer for you.

And then of course, we
haven't stopped working
on what we used to call SageMaker,
we now call SageMaker AI
as part of this next edition of SageMaker.

And one of the interesting
innovations that we launched

about a year or two ago
was SageMaker HyperPods.

And what SageMaker HyperPods
do for you is it allows you

to distribute and
parallelize your workloads,

your training workloads
across lots of training chips
or GPU chips.

So it allows you to speed up
when you're doing training
of new workloads and new models.
But it also has a feature

where it's constantly
monitoring the infrastructure
of your workloads.

And when there's a problem,
it will automatically,

it'll identify it and
automatically repair it.
And by the way, while it's repairing it,

it will automatically
checkpoint your workloads
to the last checkpoint

so that when it repairs
the infrastructure,
it just resumes seamlessly.
So for most SageMaker AI customers,

they are using HyperPods for
their large trading workloads.
And so we've added a couple new features

in the last day or so that
I think are really excited.
I'm gonna cite two of them.

One is we've added
HyperPods task governance.
So this lets you do a few things.
So let's say...
First of all, it lets you set the priority
of what workloads are

or what training workloads
are most important to you
so that we can prioritize.
So let's say that,

let's say that you have a
certain amount of compute

and you've exceeded the
limit of your compute.

And a lot of times what
happens is you realize
after the fact,
sometimes many weeks after the fact,

that what's gonna
prioritized our workloads
are not as important to you as others.
So it's lets you set the prioritization
and then if you get to some sort of limit,
it will prioritize the workloads
that you said are most important.
And it will pause at a checkpoint,
the workloads that are less important
and automatically resume them again

when you have the capacity
to be running them all.
So that's the first thing it does.

Then, say, that you have
designated a certain amount
of compute to different priority workloads
and you're not using all that compute,
maybe at off peak times of the day.

What we'll actually do then
is reallocate that compute

to other workloads so you're
not stranding any of it idle.

And then the third thing
that's interesting is
that we had this problem inside Amazon,
which is we have

all these generative AI
applications being built
and it's pretty easy to lose track

of how many of them you have
and how much compute they have
and how much you're spending on them.
And so what this feature does,
this task governance feature does,

is it allows you to see all
your workloads being run

on HyperPod and what amount
of resource they're consuming
so that you can decide,
"Do I like what I'm spending?

Do I think all these are actually
providing the right return
to continue to spend resources
on this very, very handy feature?"
And then a second feature we just launched

in SageMaker HyperPod is
flexible training plans.
And so flexible training plans,

what's interesting is you
can now specify the amount
of instances you think you need

to be able to run whatever,
train whatever your model is,

but then a timeframe
that you're comfortable
with a training on.

Sometimes you don't have
to do it right away.

You're willing to do it
over a period of time.
And then what we will do is we will return

to you an estimate on
how long it's gonna take
and how much it's gonna cost.

And if we can't do it in the
timeframe that you specified,
we will suggest an alternative plan.

But what it does is it means
that builders don't have

to do all that heavy lifting
in setting up a trading cluster

and setting up all the
jobs to run the workloads.
It just does it all for you.
It's much easier to use.
So I'm very excited

about the SageMaker AI
innovations as well.
Second area I was gonna talk about,

so yesterday you heard me
talk about Q transformation,

where we were making it
much easier to transform

from .NET to Java or Linux
to be able to transform
from VMware instances to EC2 instances
and to be able to transform mainframes
and dissect the different pieces

to go from many years
in migrating a mainframe
into it being just a few months.

And I actually really
wanted to call that feature
instead of Q Transform,

I wanted to call it the TDK
or the technical debt killer.

And that's because it kills
so much technical debt,

and any team that actually
does software development knows

that so much of your time is
spent on this technical debt

or the muck of software development
instead of writing code.
And so we have, you know,
Q transformation is part of Q Developer

and Q Developer is the
very best AI assistant
for software development.
And so we launched three other things
that we think really will remove some
of this technical debt.
The first is,
and they're all agents by the way,
as part of this.
The first is really around documentation.

So there are so many
times where as developers,

you pick up code that
you haven't worked with
and you just have no idea about the code.
Now you can actually ask for Q

to actually give you a
description of that code
and it will load into a README file.
So you actually get familiarity
with that code pretty quickly.

Same thing by the way,
when you build code,

a lot of times you don't
wanna have to take the time
to document that code.

You can just use this
Q documentation agent

to specify what the code is
so others know what it is.
The second is really around unit tests.
So we used to have in Q, we,
for a while we've had in Q,
the ability to do a unit test
on a piece of code you've written.
But now we've expanded it
so that you can actually do unit tests
on an entire end-to-end project,

which will speed up the work
you normally have to do.
And then the last piece

that we added in agent four
is really around code reviews.

And I cannot count how many
times in my history at Amazon
and in AWS that we would have some sort
of operational error.
And when we went
and did the root cause analysis,
we would often find

that we just missed it in the
reviews, the human reviews,

of when we were actually
doing code reviews.
And even when we had two-person reviews,
we'd sometimes miss it.

And so to have an agent
that in an automated way,
where they're not gonna be distracted
to be the first line of defense
in doing code reviews is incredibly handy
for development teams.

So I'm very excited about
those Q Developer launches.

Then the last thing I was
gonna mention is, you know,

today being the very last
full day of re:Invent,

I thought I would just
give you a few stats
I thought were interesting.

So we had about 60,000
total attendees here
at re:Invent this week.

We had about 150,000
total sleeping room nights

with a peak of 30,000
rooms on Tuesday night.
There were over 21,

there were 21 hotels
across the Vegas strip
that participated in re:Invent,
hosting meetings or people sleeping there.
We had 2,000 learning sessions
with 247,000 session starts.

About 2,000 companies
brought five people or more.

We'll have about 18 to
20,000 people coming
to the concert tonight.

We had about 1,200 people
participate in our 5K,
which we've been doing for a few years.
We had 186 people get tattoos here.

We had 2,200 participants on
our slide that we created.
We had a 27,000 people come to our expo.
That's a record for us.

And then we had someone
set up in our lounge

to do November haircuts
and mustache trimmings,
and we had over a hundred people do that.
So it was a very productive,
somewhat quirky, very inventive week here.

And I'd just like to
say that for all of us
that work at Amazon,

this is one of our very, very
favorite weeks of the year.

We work really hard to
try and build you features
and services and capabilities
and make it easier for you

to improve your customer
experiences and your businesses.

And we're always heads down
trying to deliver it for you,

but to have a chance to
spend a week with all of you
and to hear what you're doing
on top of the platform is very inspiring.
So thanks for spending the week with us

and we look forward to
seeing you again next year.
